abstract.p: Block-by-block guide to New York Is Book Country fair on Fifth Avenue (M)

block.p: Activities related to literature, from readings of printed novels to panel discussions on computer-generated texts, are to be offered over the next three days during the 22nd New York Is Book Country festival.

''A Book, E-Book, Any Book'' is the theme of the festival's centerpiece, the fair that takes place on Sunday along Fifth Avenue from 48th to 57th Streets in Manhattan. Emeril Lagasse, the chef and television personality, will serve as grand marshal and will give a cooking demonstration at 2 p.m.

Activities related to literature, from readings of printed novels to panel discussions on computer-generated texts, are to be offered over the next three days during the 22nd New York Is Book Country festival.

''A Book, E-Book, Any Book'' is the theme of the festival's centerpiece, the fair that takes place on Sunday along Fifth Avenue from 48th to 57th Streets in Manhattan. Emeril Lagasse, the chef and television personality, will serve as grand marshal and will give a cooking demonstration at 2 p.m.

Authors and illustrators, among them Mary Higgins Clark, will make appearances at the booths where literary material from more than 200 exhibitors, from major publishers to small presses, will be available from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., weather permitting; the fair, which is free, may be canceled if it rains heavily. Information: (212) 207-7242.

Free maps of the booth sites will be available at an information booth on the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 52d Street. A special feature this year is a New Technology Pavilion, an interactive display sponsored by RCA eBook that will offer a look at innovations in e-book publishing. Special activities will take place at two stages. One, at 53d Street, will feature entertainment for children, including storytelling, music and a performance by young members of the Lee Strasberg children's Actors Troupe. Mr. Lagasse will take to the second stage, at 48th Street, to offer book signings from noon to 5 p.m. and a cooking demonstration at 2 p.m.

Several social events with literary ties, one especially for children, are planned in Manhattan. Sunday from 10 a.m. to noon, a ''Book and Author Breakfast for Kids'' will be held at F.A.O. Schwarz, Fifth Avenue at 58th Street. The event, sponsored by the Books for Kids Foundation, features appearances by Judy Blume, James Howe, John Bemelmans Marciano and others, as well as performances by the Between the Lions Puppets and Broadway Kids. Admission is $50, or $175 for a family of four. Reservations are required: (212) 252-9168.

On Sunday at noon, a brunch sponsored by New York Is Book Country and The New York Times will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Park Avenue at 50th Street. Scheduled to appear are Candace Bushnell, Arthur Miller, Cynthia Ozick, Liz Smith and Nicholas Sparks. Admission is $110; $100 for Times Card members. Information: (888) 698-1870.

Also at the Waldorf-Astoria on Sunday will be an afternoon tea at 4 called ''Thrillers With a Capital Tea,'' with Joe R. Lansdale, April Smith, Andrew Vachss and Donald E. Westlake. Admission is $65; $60 for Times Card members. Information: (888) 698-1870.

A block-by-block guide to the Fifth Avenue fair follows. ''General interest'' refers to a section that has no unifying theme. Green balloons will indicate booths selling merchandise and yellow ones booths with displays. Two red balloons will indicate booths with books and activities for children.
48TH TO 49TH STREET. West side: general interest and audio books. East side: general interest and stage with book signing and cooking demonstration.
49TH TO 50TH STREET. East side: general interest and business.
50TH TO 51ST STREET. West side: general interest and storytelling.

51ST TO 52ND STREET. West side: general interest; The New York Times Crossword Puzzle, with Will Shortz; books for teenagers; and a booth for aspiring young writers with Judy Blume and other writers. East side: general interest.
52ND TO 53RD STREET. West side: New York Is Book Country information booth, theme merchandise; East side: theater and film.
52ND STREET. Between Madison Avenue and Avenue of the Americas: Antiquarian Row, with old and rare books.
53RD STREET. Between Madison Avenue and Avenue of the Americas: children's stage.
53RD STREET. Between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas: New Technology Pavilion.
53RD TO 54TH STREET. West side: general interest, audio books. East side: general interest.
54TH TO 55TH STREET. West side: general interest. East side: black and multicultural studies.
55TH TO 56TH STREET. West side: Jewish interest. East side: New York City interest.
56TH TO 57TH STREET. West side: art books and mysteries. East side: general interest.
